description: From Middle English pose, from Old English ġeposu pl (“cold in the head; catarrh”, literally “(the) sneezes; (the) snorts”), from Old English pos, ġepos (“sneeze, snort”), from Proto-West Germanic *pos, from Proto-Germanic *pusą (“sneeze, snort”), from Proto-Germanic *pusōną, *pusjaną (“to snort, blow”), from Proto-Indo-European *bew- (“to blow, swell”). Compare Low German pusten (“to blow, puff”), German dialectal pfausen (“to sneeze, snort”), Norwegian dialectal pysa (“to blow”).

examples: Now  […]  have we many chimnies, and yet our tenderlings complain of rheums, catarrhs, and poses.

description: From Middle English posen, from Old French poser (“to put, place, stell, settle, lodge”), from Vulgar Latin pausāre (“to blin, cease, pause”), from Latin pausa (“pause”), from Ancient Greek παῦσις (paûsis); influenced by Latin pōnere. Doublet of pause.

entries.meaning: Position, posture, arrangement (especially of the human body).
examples: Please adopt a more graceful pose for my camera.

verbs.description: pose (third-person singular simple present poses, present participle posing, simple past and past participle posed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To place in an attitude or fixed position, for the sake of effect.
examples: To pose a model for a picture.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To ask; to set (a test, quiz, riddle, etc.).
(transitive) To constitute (a danger, a threat, a risk, etc.).
examples: Rather, they are concerned with the threat Iran poses to the region and the world.

entries.meaning: (transitive, in the phrase "to pose as") To falsely impersonate (another person or occupation) primarily for the purpose of accomplishing something or reaching a goal.
(intransitive) To assume or maintain a pose; to strike an attitude.
(intransitive) To behave affectedly in order to attract interest or admiration.

examples: She pretended to  […]  pose him and sift him.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To question with a view to puzzling; to embarrass by questioning or scrutiny; to bring to a stand.

description: From Middle English posen, a combination of aphetic forms of Middle English aposen and opposen. More at appose, oppose.

verbs.description: pose (third-person singular simple present poses, present participle posing, simple past and past participle posed)

entries.meaning: (now rare) to puzzle, non-plus, or embarrass with difficult questions.
